turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: It's clear. They'll do everything possible to make it fail.

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: No, they'll do even more. We've given them the opportunity to do a lot more ... Do you understand what I mean? Starting tomorrow, they won't be groping in the dark any more; every shop and every worker who strikes will be a known enemy, a self-confessed criminal ... And they will be able to pass to the offensive. Have you thought of this?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: No ...

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: But Kader told me that you weren't in favor of the strike.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: No, and neither were my men.

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Because they told us that we mustn't use weapons, now, when the time is right.

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: That's true ... Wars aren't won with terrorism, neither wars nor revolutions. Terrorism is a beginning but afterward, all the people must act ... This is the reason for the strike, and its necessity: to mobilize all Algerians, count them and measure their strength ...

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: To show them to the UN, right?

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: Yes ... yes. The problem also involves the UN. I don't know what it's worth, but this way, we'll give the UN the possibility of evaluating our strength.

turns.speaker: ARNAUD
turns.text: Good evening ... Can we pass?

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: It's too late. No one is allowed to enter the Casbah at this hour. It's impossible.

turns.speaker: ARNAUD
turns.text: But it's not even midnight yet!

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: It's ten minutes past midnight. Curfew begins at midnight.

turns.speaker: ARNAUD
turns.text: Please, we just want to take a short ride. A friend of mine has never seen the Casbah.

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: I'm sorry. Tomorrow. Tonight is out of the question.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER
turns.text: Where were we?

turns.speaker: EMPLOYEE
turns.text: Intersection, between Consular Street and General Laquiere Avenue ...

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER
turns.text: Good, thank you, Corbiere... . See you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: EMPLOYEE
turns.text: Good evening, sir.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER
turns.text: Tell me ... Where is this rue de Thèbes?

turns.speaker: EMPLOYEE
turns.text: Rue de Thèbes? In the Upper Casbah, I think ...

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER
turns.text: All right. See you tomorrow, Corbiere.

turns.speaker: EMPLOYEE
turns.text: Good evening, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Mathieu! Mathieu, a name ...

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: A name?

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Yes, a name for the operation.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: And so the tapeworm no longer has a head. Are you satisfied, Mathieu? In Algiers everything should be over.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Yes, I believe there won't be any more talk of the NLF for some time.

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Let's hope forever.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Bah, for that matter, Algeria isn't the only country in the world ...

turns.speaker: GENERAL
turns.text: Why, yes, of course ... But for the moment, let's be satisfied with Algiers! In the mountains our work is always easier.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: For many months, I've had your photo on my desk together with a dozen or so reports on you ... And naturally, I am under the illusion that I know you somewhat. You never seemed the type, Kader, inclined to performing useless actions.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: You seem to be very satisfied to have taken me alive ...

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Of course I am.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: That proves that I was wrong. Evidently I credited you with an advantage greater than I should have.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: No. Let's just say that you've given me the satisfaction to have guessed correctly. But from the technical point of view, it isn't possible to speak of advantages. By now the game is over. The NLF has been defeated.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: What is she saying?

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: She says that Ali is still in the Casbah.

turns.speaker: MOURAD
turns.text: Who is speaking?

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Mathieu. Colonel Mathieu.

turns.speaker: MOURAD
turns.text: We don't trust you, colonel. Come forward, show yourself.

turns.speaker: MOURAD
turns.text: Okay. But we want your promise for a fair trial in writing. Give us a written statement, Mathieu, and then we'll surrender.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: How can I give you this statement?

turns.speaker: MOURAD
turns.text: We'll lower a basket from the window ...

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Okay, I'll make the statement in writing ...

turns.speaker: MOURAD
turns.text: Are you ready, colonel?

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Yes ... But let me first see you.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: How you doin' Mister D?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Fine, Charlie.  You familiar with the Marsh case?

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: Yeah -- I hear they had 'em a real dog and pony show going on up there - -  I'll tell you, sometimes white people are a real puzzle to me.  I mean, did this old guy really think he was gonna be able to keep up with a sweet little number like that?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: It could've happened to anyone.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: I'm sorry, man -- but I ain't ever heard of no brother dying from gettin' too much pussy.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: We have to find out who else would profit from Marsh's death -- and who knew enough about his personal life to know that putting cocaine in the nasal spray would be fatal.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: So -- where do we start?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I want you to hit all the dealers in town.  Give them a list of people close to Marsh and see if any of them use.  Then I want you to check out a Doctor Alan Paley.  He lives up in Roseburg.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: Before you ask there's nothing new on the coke.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You've got to get me something I can use, Charlie.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: I'm trying.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: I've been waiting for you to get back.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You got something on the coke?

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: No -- but I got something.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: I would have missed it -- but the phone rang and I let it play while I talked.  It looks like blank tape -- but it isn't.  It's been erased without any input signal coming in.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: So, what good is it to us if it's been erased?

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: It's very good -- because when the D.A's office saw it they assumed it was the end of the tape, otherwise they would have buried it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: Because it hasn't all been erased.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: I'm sorry to barge in -- but I figured after that bombshell that got laid on you today you could use some good news?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You got something on the Coke?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Charlie -- are you going to make a point soon?

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: Right now.  Guess who's been buying Coke from him for the last five and half years?

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: Joanne Braslow is getting more and more interesting.  I followed her today to an attorney's office. Joseph Koehler.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Joe Koehler.  I know him.  He's an estate attorney -- and he's very expensive.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: What would Joanne Braslow need with an estate attorney?  She wasn't even mentioned in Marsh's will.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Here it is!  According to the old will Joanne Braslow was to inherit two hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: What good does that do -- it's the old will?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Under the law a person cannot profit from their own wrong doing.  Since Rebecca Lawson is the sole beneficiary of the new will, if she is found guilty the will is void and Joanne Braslow could make a very good case to have the old will reinstated.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: She kills the old man and makes it look like Miss Lawson did it.  Pretty slick.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Take some time off.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: You think the D.A.'s gonna file on Joanne?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You did a good job, Charlie.

turns.speaker: BIGGS
turns.text: Thanks, Mister D.

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: I don't think that this is the time, or the place.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: I just wanted to introduce myself and inform Miss Lawson that there will be an inquiry.

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: An inquiry into what?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: For starters I'd like to know why she left the house and didn't report the death?

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: Because he wasn't dead when she left, and even if he was, not reporting a natural death in a timely fashion isn't a crime.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did I say it was a natural death?

turns.speaker: TROXELL
turns.text: Marsh's Cardiologist told me that after Marsh was diagnosed with heart disease he quit smoking, quit drinking and started exercising every day.  Does that sound like a guy who'd start shoveling cocaine up his nose?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What did he say about Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: TROXELL
turns.text: He can remember at least one occasion -- and the receptionist can recall two times when she accompanied Marsh to the office.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: So she knew about his heart?

turns.speaker: TROXELL
turns.text: Had to.  I also interviewed three women who were in past relationships with Marsh.  There's no evidence that he had anything but straight sex prior to meeting Miss Lawson.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What about the will?

turns.speaker: TROXELL
turns.text: That's the best part.  She gets it all -- everything.

turns.speaker: TROXELL
turns.text: I think I'm going to make your day.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: TROXELL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Then you can go.

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: About three hours.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Cause?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Not sure.  I'll have everything you need tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Marsh wasn't alone.  We found traces of sperm on the sheets.  The toxicology report says there were high levels of cocaine in his blood.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What'd he die of?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: The official cause of death was a cardiac arrest.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: The official cause?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: That's what my report will read.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: But there's more?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What are you saying, Henry?  That his girlfriend fucked him to death?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What can we prove?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: We know Marsh had a head cold.   We found cocaine mixed with water in a nasal spray container on the nightstand.  The coke would contract the nasal membrane the same as any decongestant, but for a much shorter time.  He'd keep using more and more -- never knowing what he was taking.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Any prints on the nasal spray?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Cocaine is the last thing a man in his condition would want.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Can we put Rebecca Lawson at the scene?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Doctor McCurdy, what was the cause of death?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: A massive cardiac arrest.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What was Mr. Marsh's physical condition prior to his death?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Very poor.  He was suffering from severe arterial disease.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Was the heart attack the result of natural causes?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What induced it?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: We found a high concentration of cocaine in his blood.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: So, Mr. Marsh used cocaine?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: I don't think so.  The membrane in his nasal passage didn't show any sign of long time usage.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Then how did it get into his body?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: We found a bottle of Dristan nasal spray on the nightstand.  It was filled with water and cocaine.  Mr. Marsh had a head cold at the time of his death.  I believe he wasn't aware that he was ingesting cocaine.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Is this the bottle that was found on the nightstand?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Your Honor, the State enters this evidence as exhibit A.  Were any fingerprints found on the bottle?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Yes -- those of Mr. Marsh and a thumb print of Miss Lawson's.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Dr. McCurdy, what would cocaine do to someone in Mr. Marsh's condition?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: Increase his heart rate.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: -- And if he were in the midst of making love while under the influence of cocaine?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: It would be an added stress to his heart.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What would be the effect if someone secretly administered cocaine to Mr. Marsh and then induced him to make love?

turns.speaker: MCCURDY
turns.text: It would be the same as shooting a gun at him.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Thank you, Doctor McCurdy.  Your witness.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Mrs. Crawford, you were Mr. Marsh's maid for nine years?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did Miss Lawson and Mr. Marsh ever argue?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: Like cats and dogs.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What did they argue about?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: You name it -- they argued about it. Mr. Marsh tried his best to keep her happy -- but it seemed that no matter what he did it was never enough for her.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did they argue the day before he died?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: Well -- he died on a Sunday and I have the weekends off -- but they were ripping at each other with both barrels Friday afternoon.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What was the nature of the argument?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: Sex.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Could you be more specific?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you ever see Mr. Marsh use cocaine?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: No -- never.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Your witness.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Your Honor, Mr. Roston is an ex-lover of Miss Lawson's.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Why didn't the State's investigation uncover Mr. Roston earlier?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: He was away on an extended vacation and just returned two days ago.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Alright -- I'm going to allow his testimony.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Objection sustained.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did Miss Lawson ever give you any indication why she was leaving?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: No questions.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: You may call your next witness.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Objection, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Counsel approach the bench.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: That's it.  My client doesn't have to take this crap from you.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Sit down, Frank.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No.  Miss Lawson came in here voluntarily to answer your questions. She doesn't have to sit here and be insulted.  So, either you charge her now or we're leaving.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Lookin' to make the papers, John?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Marsh left her close to three million dollars in his will.  That's motive. She admits to being there the night of his death.  That's opportunity -- and her fingerprints are on the nasal spray bottle.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You can't show intent.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Can you?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Take your pole out of the water, Frank.  The fish ain't biting today.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You're bluffing.  John, it's me, remember?  I've known you since your name was Juan Carlos.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: C'mon -- think about it.  If she was going to kill Marsh why leave the nasal spray bottle there for the police to find?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: She planned this.  She wanted us to find the nasal spray.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why would she want that?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Because she's clever.  Because she knows that even if we didn't find it we'd have suspicions as to why a man in Marsh's condition would use cocaine.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Suspicions maybe -- but suspicions aren't enough for a conviction.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: The M.E.'s report stated that Marsh's nasal membranes showed no sign of prior cocaine use.  Without the nasal spray we would have still treated it as a poisoning.  We would have looked for motive and the trail would have still led back to her.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I don't buy it and neither will a jury.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: We're going all the way on this one, Frank.  Tell your client she has until the prelim to cop a plea for murder two -- fifteen to twenty five.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'll tell her but she won't take it.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Then she's not as smart as I thought she was.  You've seen her in the depositions.  Tell me you don't have any doubts?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: She's innocent.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Aren't they all?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Yeah.  Well -- we'll let the blindfolded lady with the scales decide that.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Your Honor, this is a tape from Miss Lawson's answering machine.  I would like to play it now.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Objection.  Your Honor, we don't know where this tape is from.  Who made it -- or under what circumstances it was made.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Your Honor, I fail to see what Mrs Crawford's educational background has to do with this case.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I was just about to make my point, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Objection, Your Honor.  The fact that Mrs. Crawford heard Mr. Troxell reconstruct her sentence and decided to rephrase her words in a more intelligent manner for the court doesn't mean the incident never happened.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm just curious to see if Mr. Troxell reconstructed anything else.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Your Honor -- please!

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I've got work to do.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Hey -- the bell's sounded.  It's between rounds.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I didn't hear it.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What's happening to you, Frank? You're acting like you're on trial here.  This has become personal to you.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Back off, John.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: That's ridiculous.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: I'm talking to you as a friend now. Don't ruin your life, your career for her.  She'll spit you out when this is over.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Really?  What does an attorney speak to his client about at her house until three o'clock in the morning?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You've been following me?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Her.  It's an obvious move.  I'm building a case against her, remember?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Your Honor, I don't see a Mr. Roston listed as a prosecution witness.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: The State's investigation just uncovered Mr. Roston yesterday afternoon in Chicago.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Objection.  The question calls for a conclusion on the part of the witness.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Your Honor, Mr. Roston lived with the defendant for many months.  I feel that his opinion is valid in substantiating the character of the Miss Lawson.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: The opinion of a scorned lover is hardly an objective view.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'll rephrase the question.  Mr. Roston isn't it true you are bisexual?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Objection!  Mr. Roston's sexual preferences are not at issue in this trial.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Your Honor, I'm trying to establish the sense of betrayal Miss Lawson felt when she discovered the man she lived with was a different person than she thought he was.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Objection!  May I remind Mr. Dulaney that the person on trial here is Miss Lawson -- not Dr. Paley.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Your Honor, I'm trying to establish a pattern in Dr. Paley's behavior with women.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Can I go?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: You get his statement?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Miss Lawson, do you use cocaine?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I have.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you use it the night Marsh died?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No.  I haven't done it in years.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Were you aware of Mr. Marsh's heart condition?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Mr. Marsh's Cardiologist and his nurse have told us that you accompanied Mr. Marsh to their office on at least two occasions.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: That's correct -- but Andrew never told me he had a heart condition.  He said he had a heart arrhythmia and it was nothing serious.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Miss Braslow -- I'm District Attorney John Cardenas.  You arrived at what time tonight?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: A little after eleven.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Why did you come by?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I had some papers to pick up.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Do you know who Mr. Marsh was with?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I assume his girlfriend.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Her name?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Rebecca Lawson.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: You wouldn't know her address, would you?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: No -- but I can get it for you.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: How long were you Mr Marsh's personal secretary?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Six years.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you ever see Mr. Marsh use Cocaine?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: No -- never.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What about Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Tell the court about that, please.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I opened the bathroom door one day and saw Miss Lawson pouring Cocaine out of a vial.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you see Mr. Marsh the day before his death?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: How did he look?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Horrible.  He was tired and pale.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you talk about Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What did Mr. Marsh say?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Is it Marsh?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Who found him?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: His Secretary.  Joanne Braslow.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: She was here?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: No.  She stopped by to pick up some papers.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Show me.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Doctor Trammel, when did you first diagnose that Mr. Marsh had heart disease?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: About a year and half ago.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did Mr. Marsh change his lifestyle after that?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: Yes -- he stopped smoking and drinking and exercised regularly.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: He did everything he could to take care of his heart?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did Miss Lawson ever accompany Mr. Marsh to your office?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Just one last question.  What does the sign on your office door say?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: Doctor Steven Trammel.  Cardiologist.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Mr. Roston, what was your relationship with Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: We were lovers.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: How long were you together?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: For about one year.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: How would you describe your sex life with Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Intense.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: I know this is a very personal subject, but could you be a little more specific?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: It was wild.  She was constantly trying to get me more and more worked up -- kinky things.  I tried to satisfy her the best I could, but it was difficult in my condition.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What kind of condition are you referring to?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: I had a bad heart.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What happened next?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: I had bypass surgery.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: And how are you now?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Fine.  The doctors say if I keep taking care of myself I can live to be a very old man.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: How did your relationship with Miss Lawson progress after the surgery?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: It didn't.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: She left me.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Why did she say she was leaving?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: She didn't.  She just left.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Why do you think she left you?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Well -- I think that after the operation she realized that...

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: When you say your sexual relations with Miss Lawson were intense what exactly do you mean?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: It was like she was trying to push me as far as she could.  She called it opening new doors.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Can you give the court an example?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: It was like sex was a game to her. She got off on the control.  She always used to tell me it had to be her way.

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: It's hard to resist a woman as beautiful as she is.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What would she do that made it hard to resist?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: She's a woman who is very much aware of her own sexuality.  Sometimes I felt she could read my mind.  It was uncanny how she knew exactly what I wanted.  A few nights before my heart surgery Rebecca woke me.  She had handcuffed me to the bed.

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: She told me that tonight we were going to open new doors.  I asked her to stop -- to take off the handcuffs, but she wouldn't listen.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What did she say?

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Mr. Roston I know this is difficult for you, but it's important you tell the court what she did.

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: She said she was going to fuck me like I've never been fucked before.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What did she do next, Mr. Roston?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: She started touching herself and telling me how much she wanted me. She reached down and put me inside her.  My doctor had warned me about exerting myself -- but you really don't think of those things at a moment like that.  You just think about how beautiful this woman is -- how much you want her.  How deeply you want to please her.  At first it started off slowly -- but the rhythm built and built.    Every time I got close to an orgasm she would stop.  Eventually I started to have trouble breathing.  Rebecca just kept going -- faster and faster.  No matter what I said she wouldn't stop. I really thought for a moment I was going to die.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: If you knew it was bad for you why did you do it?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: I couldn't help myself.  You get lost inside a women like her.  It was like a drug.  It was the best sex I ever had.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What happened after that?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: I woke up the next morning and she was gone.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you change your will while you were with Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Who was your primary beneficiary?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: She was.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Thank you.  The State rests.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Where did you meet Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: At a dinner party -- about eight months ago.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you ever see her again after that?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: Yes -- several times.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What eventually happened to your relationship with Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: We stopped seeing each other.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: Well -- I realized that she wasn't interested in me.  She was just trying to get information out of me.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What kind of information?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: She said that she was working on a novel and she wanted to know what kinds of drugs would be harmful to someone with a bad heart.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: Did you suggest any?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: Yes -- Insulin and others.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: What did she say?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: She said that those weren't any good -- because their use would be detected and the police would know the victim had been poisoned.  She wanted to know if there was a drug that would induce a heart attack but could also be used to enhance a sexual high.

turns.speaker: CARDENAS
turns.text: -- And what did you suggest?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: Cocaine.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Dr. Paley, where were you the last time you saw Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: We had dinner at a restaurant.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Isn't it true that later that night you tried to force yourself on Miss Lawson in the parking lot?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You didn't grab her and try to kiss her?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: If necessary I can bring in the valet parking attendant and two customers who witnessed the occurrence.

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: Well -- as I remember it, we had an argument.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: And the argument was about the fact that you wanted to be romantically involved and she did not.

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: And after that didn't you continuously harass Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You'll be sorry?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: I was angry.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You're still angry, aren't you? Isn't it true that your whole story is nothing more than a vindictive attempt on your behalf to get back at Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: No -- she asked me about cocaine.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I suggest it never happened.

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: You can suggest anything you want. It happened.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No further questions.

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: I may have been infatuated with her - - but I wouldn't perjure myself.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: That's all Dr. Paley.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Don't you see what she's doing?  She needs you to kill me.  She's planned it that way from the start.  That's why she phoned me tonight.

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: You called him?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm sure that every orgasm she had with me was faked.

turns.speaker: DR. PALEY
turns.text: That's enough.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I mean she only screwed me two or three times a night because she had to -- I'm sure she didn't enjoy it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Dr. Trammel, did you ever speak to Miss Lawson about Mr. Marsh's condition?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Did Mr. Marsh ever tell you that he had spoken to Miss Lawson about his illness?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Did Miss Lawson ever accompany Mr. Marsh inside during his examinations?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Then you have no way of knowing what Mr. Marsh told Miss Lawson were the reasons for his visits?

turns.speaker: DR. TRAMMEL
turns.text: No.  No, I don't.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Dr. Wong -- what type of medicine do you practice?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: Oriental medicine.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: --And is Miss Lawson a patient of yours?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: Yes.  I've been seeing her for over a year.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why does she come to you?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: She suffers from severe menstrual cramps.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Did you ever prescribe any medication for her cramps?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What did you prescribe for her?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: Chinese peony root.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Would you describe for the court what Chinese peony root looks like?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: It's a white powder that comes in a vial.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How do you instruct your patients to take it?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: I tell them to pour an amount the size of a quarter into the their hand and mix it with water.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: A previous witness stated that she saw Miss Lawson pouring a white powder into her hand on October twenty-eighth.  According to your records when did you prescribe the drug?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: October twenty-seventh.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: One last question, Doctor.  If someone didn't know better, would it be easy to mistake the peony root for cocaine?

turns.speaker: DR. WONG
turns.text: Yes -- quite easy.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Did you go to college, Mrs. Crawford?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: High school?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: I heard him say it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Then -- those are not your own words?

turns.speaker: ESTER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What else did the District Attorney's Office tell you to say?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Miss Sellers, do you know Dr. Alan Paley?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Where did you meet him?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: I'm a nurse.  I used to work at Roseburg Memorial Hospital.  Dr. Paley's on staff there.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What was the nature of your relationship with Dr. Paley.

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: We dated for about a month last year.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Then what happened?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: I realized he wasn't serious.  He was seeing other women -- asking other nurses at the hospital out, so I ended it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: -- And what did Dr. Paley do after you stopped seeing him?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: He used to call me -- tell me that I couldn't just walk out on him.  He said that if I didn't come back he'd make my life miserable.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Did he make your life miserable?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: Yes -- he did.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: He laughed -- and basically said he would decide when it was over.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Do you remember his exact words?
